articles.headline: Republicans Revive 2018 Strategy, Hoping for Better Result: Scare Voters
articles.snippet: President Trump and his party are using a playbook that aims to alarm people about crime in their backyards. It didn’t work in 2018, but both parties think it could resonate more this year.
articles.abstract: President Trump and his party are using a playbook that aims to alarm people about crime in their backyards. It didn’t work in 2018, but both parties think it could resonate more this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Republicans were done with Sharice Davids in 2018, she barely recognized herself. In ads that blanketed her suburban Kansas City district during her congressional race, she was portrayed as “the candidate of the liberal mob,” an enemy of the police, a threat to children, and an ally of “radical left-wing protesters.”

articles.headline: The Fed Enabled a Record Expansion. Trump Is Taking Credit.
articles.snippet: President Trump has taken credit for the lowest unemployment rate in 50 years, but the Federal Reserve’s patient policies laid the groundwork.
articles.abstract: President Trump has taken credit for the lowest unemployment rate in 50 years, but the Federal Reserve’s patient policies laid the groundwork.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is using the prepandemic economy to make a case for his re-election, highlighting time and again that unemployment rates fell to record low levels for Black and Hispanic workers in 2019, and that wages were climbing steadily under his watch.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Manhattan’s Office Buildings Are Empty. But for How Long?
articles.snippet: As they grow accustomed to working from home, many businesses are delaying signing new leases until rents drop and the pandemic passes.
articles.abstract: As they grow accustomed to working from home, many businesses are delaying signing new leases until rents drop and the pandemic passes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the coronavirus pandemic appears to recede in New York, corporations have been reluctant to call their workers back to their skyscrapers and are showing even more hesitation about committing to the city long term.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Boeing 787 Dreamliner Deliveries Slowed by Quality Concerns
articles.snippet: The company said it was stepping up inspections, citing new manufacturing problems. Federal regulators are also looking into production flaws.
articles.abstract: The company said it was stepping up inspections, citing new manufacturing problems. Federal regulators are also looking into production flaws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing said Tuesday that it expected deliveries of its popular 787 Dreamliner to be delayed as it and the Federal Aviation Administration look into quality control concerns with the plane, a wide-body jet capable of carrying hundreds of passengers long distances.

articles.headline: ‘You Couldn’t See Anything’: Harrowing Helicopter Rescues as California Wildfires Rage
articles.snippet: The two pilots who led a weekend rescue, both military veterans, said it was the most challenging flying they have done in their careers.
articles.abstract: The two pilots who led a weekend rescue, both military veterans, said it was the most challenging flying they have done in their careers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Even over the crackling roar of the wildfire surrounding them, Daniel Crouch heard the hum of military helicopters emerging out of the smoky darkness.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: How a Massive Bomb Came Together in Beirut’s Port
articles.snippet: Fifteen tons of fireworks. Jugs of kerosene and acid. Thousands of tons of ammonium nitrate. A system of corruption and bribes let the perfect bomb sit for years.
articles.abstract: Fifteen tons of fireworks. Jugs of kerosene and acid. Thousands of tons of ammonium nitrate. A system of corruption and bribes let the perfect bomb sit for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifteen tons of fireworks. Jugs of kerosene and acid. Thousands of tons of ammonium nitrate. A system of corruption and bribes let the perfect bomb sit for years.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Maria Abi-Habib, Mona El-Naggar, Allison McCann, Anjali Singhvi, James Glanz and Jeremy White

articles.headline: Trapped by Pandemic, Ships’ Crews Fight Exhaustion and Despair
articles.snippet: When borders closed, seafarers on ships around the world suddenly had no way home. Half a year later, there’s no solution in sight.
articles.abstract: When borders closed, seafarers on ships around the world suddenly had no way home. Half a year later, there’s no solution in sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Ralph Santillan, a merchant seaman from the Philippines, hasn’t had shore leave in half a year. It has been 18 months since he reported for duty on his ship, which hauls corn, barley and other commodities around the world. It has been even longer since he saw his wife and son.
